# Dominant 7b5 Chord in C (Shape D)

The Dominant 7b5 chord, also known as the half-diminished 7 chord, is a four-note chord consisting of a root note, a major third, a diminished fifth, and a minor seventh. In the key of C, when using Shape D, the notes are D (root), F# (major third), A# (diminished fifth), and C (minor seventh).

## Notes and Intervals
- D (root)
- F# (major third)
- A# (diminished fifth)
- C (minor seventh)

The interval structure of the Dominant 7b5 chord in C using Shape D:
- Root (1)
- Major Third (3)
- Diminished Fifth (b5)
- Minor Seventh (b7)

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7b5 chord is commonly used in jazz and blues music due to its dissonant and tense quality, adding drama and tension to musical phrases. It is often used as a substitution for dominant 7 chords to create harmonic interest. This chord can create a sense of mystery and suspense in a musical piece.

## Songs
Three songs that use the Dominant 7b5 chord in C (Shape D):
1. "Blue Monk" by Thelonious Monk
2. "All The Things You Are" by Jerome Kern
3. "Autumn Leaves" by Joseph Kosma
